2.text:
I'm dangerous, on the edge, wanted. 
 A proper crim now.

5.text: Can I go down for attempted murder

6.text:
or grevious bodily harm 
 or something?

20.text: This is not who I am.

22.text:
I'm just Femi Beryl Ayodele 
 from Bermondsey.

28.text: We met at a well random bingo night.

32.text:
We've been like Marmite and cheese 
 since then.

35.text:
Like houmous and those little 
 carrot sticks.

38.text:
No, seriously, 
 we're like chips and ketchup.

43.text: Then, one day, it just got intense.

49.text:
'and you're eating out of 
 the same chicken bucket?'

51.text:
He gives me a serviette 
 to wipe the garlic mayo

65.text: But I couldn't get to my phone.

66.text: Had my hands full with a spicy wing.

72.text: So, right there, he gives me this.

76.text:
Then he says to me 
 that he went to see

79.text:
a psychic once and she told him that
 he would marry a woman from Africa.

83.text: And now I'm thinking, that's me.

95.text:
So, I invite his parents round for 
 dinner.

98.text: That's what I'm meant to do, right?

102.text: Big up my Nigerian roots, he says.

105.text:
So, one minute past one o'clock 
 and I'm running to catch

109.text:
Properly shopping for 
 African food ingredients.

117.text: Mixed with a lot of Scottish.

125.text:
I'm not even sure how to make 
 the oven work.

128.text:
I'm rushing and sweating 
 and I need to get dressed.

134.text: What's there to be nervous about?

137.text:
His mum comes in wearing an earth 
 mother and her hair in canerows.

143.text:
I knew I should have worn 
 the head wrap.

145.text:
His dad greets me in 
 five different languages.

151.text:
And I don't even know what 
 he is saying right now.

155.text:
But I go with it, 
 cos they're trying.

160.text:
Eat it with their fingers, because 
 apparently that's traditional.

164.text:
His dad says it's as good as 
 the Ethiopian restaurant

168.text:
His mum loves how much extra hot 
 pepper they always give her.

174.text:
And they're saying 
 the nicest things.

189.text:
His mum grabs my hand in hers, 
 stroking me.

194.text:
Asks my ancestors for forgiveness, 
 and I'm looking at Stephan like...

199.text: He just keeps winking at me.

202.text:
Calls me his African Queen 
 with a big grin.

205.text: Says I should ask his mum anything,

207.text:
because there's still stuff about 
 my culture she can teach me.

212.text:
And I'm back in the kitchen 
 again and I feel...

230.text: Does this chicken stew need extra?

250.text:
The biggest fail since that 
 custard drama on Bake Off.

256.text:
All I did was serve up what 
 they asked for.

259.text:
My nan used to say, "If it's pepper 
 you want, it's pepper you will get."

269.text: Why pretend to be anything I'm not?

275.text:
I am Femi Beryl Ayodele 
 from Burmondsey.
